moves.1. e4 c5: King's Pawn followed by my standard response, the Sicilian Defence.  King's Pawn has always been my favourite opening move for White, I think it avoids the slow manoeuvring type of games which I generally dislike.
moves.2. Qf3: Hmmmm, I've always been told by the guys teaching me to play that moving your Queen out early is a recipe for disaster.
moves.2... Nc6 3. Bc4: Well, the expected threat of checkmate, I'm trembling :p
moves.3... Nf6 4. d3 d5: The threat is easily deflected, so it's time to begin the punishment for a silly opening.
moves.5. exd5 Nd4: White goes up in material.  Black forks White's pawn at c2 and White's queen.  Only a simple fork, but allows me to gain some tempo.
moves.6. Qd1: Only realistic move White could make.
moves.7. c3: White offers exchange of ls-bishop for Black's knight.
moves.10. Qa4+: I preferred Qxd4 here, gaining White another piece of material and defending the vulnerable c4 pawn.  Qa4 was a fairly pointless check, easily defended with. . .
moves.10... Bd7: Bd7, which forces the Queen to retreat.
moves.11. Qb4: I think Qb3 was slightly better here. I see an opportunity to quickly. . .
moves.11... e6: threaten White's poor queen again.  She must be beginning to feel slightly picked on by now!
moves.12. Qd2: More retreating, back to pick on my vulnerable d4 pawn.
moves.12... Qxc4: Isolates White's pawn at d5 and protects my own vulnerable d4 pawn.
moves.13. Qf4: !!! Surely b3 was the correct move here?  Either way, I think it's not looking good for White, but Qf4 abandons the doomed d5 pawn, and allows me to threaten White's back-line.
moves.13... Nxd5: That places me in front in material and places another threat on White's poor bullied Queen.
moves.14. b3: I think Nd2 was better.  From what I can see, b3 will end with my winning more material and leaving White crippled.  It was the last move of the game for White, unfortunately he timed out.

gameName: Game Number 6 - Why early queen moves are best avoided
